SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter the Duke of Ephesus, with the Merchant of Siracusa, Iaylor, and other attendants

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Marchant.
SPEECH.LINE: Proceed Solinus to procure my fall,
And by the doome of death end wœs and all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Merchant of Siracusa, plead no more.
I am not partiall to infringe our Lawes;
The enmity and discord which of late
Sprung from the rancorous outrage of your Duke,
To Merchants our well-dealing Countrimen,
Who wanting gilders to redeeme their liues,
Haue ſeal’d his rigorous ſtatutes with their blouds,
Excludes all pitty from our threatning lookes:
For ſince the mortall and intestine iarres
Twixt thy ſeditious Countrimen and vs,
It hath in ſolemne Synodes beene decreed,
Both by the Siracusians and our ſelues,
To admit no trafficke to our aduerse townes:
Nay more, if any borne at Ephesus
Be ſeene at any Siracusian Marts and Fayres:
Againe, if any Siracusian borne
Come to the Bay of Ephesus, he dies:
His goods confiscate to the Dukes dispose,
Vnleſſe a thousand markes be leuied
To quit the penalty, and to ransome him:
Thy ſubstance, valued at the highest rate,
Cannot amount vnto a hundred Markes,
Therefore by Law thou art condemn’d to die.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: Yet this my comfort, when your words are done,
My wœs end likewise with the euening Sonne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: Well Siracusian; ſay in briefe the cause
Why thou departedst from thy natiue home?
And for what cause thou cam'st to Ephesus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: A heauier taske could not haue beene impos’d,
Then I to ſpeake my griefes vnspeakeable:
Yet that the world may witneſſe that my end
Was wrought by nature, not by vile offence,
Ile vtter what my ſorrow giues me leaue.
In Syracusa was I borne, and wedde
Vnto a woman, happy but for me,
And by me; had not our hap beene bad:
With her I liu’d in ioy, our wealth increast
By prosperous voyages I often made
To Epidamium, till my factors death,
And he great care of goods at randone left,
Drew me from kinde embracements of my ſpouse;
From whom my absence was not ſixe moneths olde,
Before her ſelfe (almost at fainting vnder
The pleasing punishment that women beare)
Had made prouision for her following me,
And ſoone, and ſafe, arriued where I was:
There had ſhe not beene long, but ſhe became
A ioyfull mother of two goodly ſonnes:
And, which was ſtrange, the one ſo like the other,
As could not be distinguish’d but by names.
That very howre, and in the ſelfe-ſame Inne,
A meane woman was deliuered
Of ſuch a burthen Male, twins both alike:
Those, for their parents were exceeding poore,
I bought, and brought vp to attend my ſonnes.
My wife, not meanely prowd of two ſuch boyes,
Made daily motions for our home returne:
Vnwilling I agreed, alas, too ſoone wee came aboord.
A league from Epidamium had we ſaild
Before the alwaies winde-obeying deepe
Gaue any Tragicke Instance of our harme:
But longer did we not retaine much hope;
For what obscured light the heauens did grant,
Did but conuay vnto our fearefull mindes
A doubtfull warrant of immediate death,
Which though my ſelfe would gladly haue imbrac’d,
Yet the inceſſant weepings of my wife,
Weeping before for what ſhe ſaw must come,
And pitteous playnings of the prettie babes
That mourn’d for fashion, ignorant what to feare,
Forst me to ſeeke delayes for them and me,
And this it was: (for other meanes was none)
The Sailors ſought for ſafety by our boate,
And left the ſhip then ſinking ripe to vs.
My wife, more carefull for the latter borne,
Had fastned him vnto a ſmall ſpare Mast,
Such as ſea-faring men prouide for ſtormes:
To him one of the other twins was bound,
Whil'st I had beene like heedfull of the other.
The children thus dispos’d, my wife and I,
Fixing our eyes on whom our care was fixt,
Fastned our ſelues at eyther end the mast,
And floating ſtraight, obedient to the ſtreame,
Was carried towards Corinth, as we thought.
At length the ſonne gazing vpon the earth,
Disperst those vapours that offended vs,
And by the benefit of his wished light
The ſeas waxt calme, and we discouered
Two ſhippes from farre, making amaine to vs:
Of Corinth that, of Epidarus this,
But ere they came, oh let me ſay no more,
Gather the ſequell by that went before.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay forward old man, doe not breake off ſo,
For we may pitty, though not pardon thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Merch.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh had the gods done ſo, I had not now
Worthily tearm’d them mercileſſe to vs:
For ere the ſhips could meet by twice fiue leagues,
We were encountred by a mighty rocke,
Which being violently borne vp,
Our helpefull ſhip was ſplitted in the midst;
So that in this vniust diuorce of vs,
Fortune had left to both of vs alike,
What to delight in, what to ſorrow for,
Her part, poore ſoule, ſeeming as burdened
With leſſer waight, but not with leſſer wœ,
Was carried with more ſpeed before the winde,
And in our ſight they three were taken vp
By Fishermen of Corinth, as we thought.
At length another ſhip had ſeiz’d on vs,
And knowing whom it was their hap to ſaue,
Gaue healthfull welcome to their ſhip-wrackt guests,
And would haue reft the Fishers of their prey,
Had not their backe beene very ſlow of ſaile;
And therefore homeward did they bend their course.
Thus haue you heard me ſeuer’d from my bliſſe,
That by misfortunes was my life prolong’d,
To tell ſad ſtories of my owne mishaps.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: And for the ſake of them thou ſorrowest for,
Doe me the fauour to dilate at full,
What haue befalne of them and they till now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Merch.
SPEECH.LINE: My yongest boy, and yet my eldest care,
At eighteene yeeres became inquisitiue
After his brother; and importun’d me
That his attendant, ſo his case was like,
Reft of his brother, but retain’d his name,
Might beare him company in the quest of him:
Whom whil'st I laboured of a loue to ſee,
I hazarded the loſſe of whom I lou’d.
Fiue Sommers haue I ſpent in farthest Greece,
Roming cleane through the bounds of Asia,
And coasting homeward, came to Ephesus:
Hopeleſſe to finde, yet loth to leaue vnsought
Or that, or any place that harbours men:
But heere must end the ſtory of my life,
And happy were I in my timelie death,
Could all my trauells warrant me they liue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Hapleſſe Egeon whom the fates haue markt
To beare the extremitie of dire mishap:
Now trust me, were it not against our Lawes,
Against my Crowne, my oath, my dignity,
Which Princes would they may not disanull,
My ſoule ſhould ſue as aduocate for thee:
But though thou art adiudged to the death,
And paſſed ſentence may not be recal’d
But to our honours great disparagement:
Yet will I fauour thee in what I can;
Therefore Marchant, Ile limit thee this day
To ſeeke thy helpe by beneficiall helpe,
Try all the friends thou hast in Ephesus,
Beg thou, or borrow, to make vp the ſumme,
And liue: if no, then thou art doom’d to die:
Iaylor, take him to thy custodie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iaylor.
SPEECH.LINE: I will my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Merch.
SPEECH.LINE: Hopeleſſe and helpeleſſe doth Egean wend,
But to procrastinate his liueleſſe end.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Antipholis Erotes, a Marchant, and Dromio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mer.
SPEECH.LINE: Therefore giue out you are of Epidamium,
Lest that your goods too ſoone be confiscate:
This very day a Syracusian Marchant
Is apprehended for a riuall here,
And not being able to buy out his life,
According to the ſtatute of the towne,
Dies ere the wearie ſunne ſet in the West:
There is your monie that I had to keepe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Goe beare it to the Centaure, where we host,
And ſtay there Dromio, till I come to thee;
Within this houre it will be dinner time,
Till that Ile view the manners of the towne,
Peruse the traders, gaze vpon the buildings,
And then returne and ſleepe within mine Inne,
For with long trauaile I am ſtiffe and wearie.
Get thee away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Many a man would take you at your word,
And goe indeede, hauing ſo good a meane.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: A trustie villaine ſir, that very oft,
When I am dull with care and melancholly,
Lightens my humour with his merry iests:
What will you walke with me about the towne,
And then goe to my Inne and dine with me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: I am inuited ſir to certaine Marchants,
Of whom I hope to make much benefit:
I craue your pardon, ſoone at fiue a clocke,
Please you, Ile meete with you vpon the Mart,
And afterward consort you till bed time:
My present busineſſe cals me from you now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell till then: I will goe loose my ſelfe,
And wander vp and downe to view the Citie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I commend you to your owne content.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: He that commends me to mine owne content,
Commends me to the thing I cannot get:
I to the world am like a drop of water,
That in the Ocean ſeekes another drop,
Who falling there to finde his fellow forth,
(Vnseene, inquisitiue) confounds himselfe.
So I, to finde a Mother and a Brother,
In quest of them (vnhappie a) loose my ſelfe.
Here comes the almanacke of my true date:
What now? How chance thou art return’d ſo ſoone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Return’d ſo ſoone, rather approacht too late:
The Capon burnes, the Pig fals from the ſpit;
The clocke hath ſtrucken twelue vpon the bell:
My Mistris made it one vpon my cheeke:
She is ſo hot because the meate is colde:
The meate is colde, because you come not home:
You come not home, because you haue no ſtomacke:
You haue no ſtomacke, hauing broke your fast:
But we that know what ‘tis to fast and pray,
Are penitent for your default to day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Stop in your winde ſir, tell me this I pray?
Where haue you left the mony that I gaue you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh ſixe pence that I had a wensday last,
To pay the Sadler for my Mistris crupper:
The Sadler had it Sir, I kept it not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: I am not in a ſportiue humor now:
Tell me, and dally not, where is the monie?
We being ſtrangers here, how dar'st thou trust
So great a charge from thine owne custodie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you iest ſir as you ſit at dinner:
I from my Mistris come to you in post:
If I returne I ſhall be post indeede.
For ſhe will ſcoure your fault vpon my pate:
Me thinkes your maw, like mine, ſhould be your cooke,
And ſtrike you home without a meſſenger.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Come Dromio, come, these iests are out of ſeason,
Reserue them till a merrier houre then this:
Where is the gold I gaue in charge to thee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: To me ſir? why you gaue no gold to me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Come on ſir knaue, haue done your foolishnes,
And tell me how thou hast dispos’d thy charge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: My charge was but to fetch you fro[m] the Mart
Home to your house, the Phœnix ſir, to dinner;
My Mistris and her ſister ſtaies for you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Now as I am a Christian anſwer me,
In what ſafe place you haue bestow’d my monie;
Or I ſhall breake that merrie ſconce of yours
That ſtands on tricks, when I am vndispos’d:
Where is the thousand Markes thou hadst of me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue ſome markes of yours vpon my pate:
Some of my Mistris markes vpon my ſhoulders:
But not a thousand markes betweene you both.
If I ſhould pay your worship those againe,
Perchance you will not beare them patiently.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Thy Mistris markes? what Mistris ſlaue hast thou?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Your worships wife, my Mistris at the Phœnix;
She that doth fast till you come home to dinner:
And praies that you will hie you home to dinner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: What wilt thou flout me thus vnto my face
Being forbid? There take you that ſir knaue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: What meane you ſir, for God ſake hold your hands:
Nay, and you will not ſir, Ile take my heeles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Vpon my life by ſome deuise or other,
The villaine is ore-wrought of all my monie.
They ſay this towne is full of cosenage:
As nimble Iuglers that deceiue the eie:
Darke working Sorcerers that change the minde:
Soule-killing Witches, that deforme the bodie:
Disguised Cheaters, prating Mountebankes;
And manie ſuch like liberties of ſinne:
If it proue ſo, I will be gone the ſooner:
Ile to the Centaur to goe ſeeke this ſlaue,
I greatly feare my monie is not ſafe.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Adriana, wife to Antipholis Sereptus, with Luciana her Sister

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: Neither my husband nor the ſlaue return’d,
That in ſuch haste I ſent to ſeeke his Master?
Sure Luciana it is two a clocke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Perhaps ſome Merchant hath inuited him,
And from the Mart he's ſomewhere gone to dinner:
Good Sister let vs dine, and neuer fret;
A man is Master of his libertie:
Time is their Master, and when they ſee time,
They'll goe or come; if ſo, be patient Sister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ſhould their libertie then ours be more?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Because their busineſſe ſtill lies out a dore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: Looke when I ſerue him ſo, he takes it thus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh, know he is the bridle of your will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: There's none but aſſes will be bridled ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, headstrong liberty is lasht with wœ:
There's nothing ſituate vnder heauens eye,
But hath his bound in earth, in ſea, in ſkie.
The beasts, the fishes, and the winged fowles
Are their males ſubiects, and at their controules:
Man more diuine, the Master of all these,
Lord of the wide world, and wilde watry ſeas,
Indued with intellectuall ſence and ſoules,
Of more preheminence then fish and fowles,
Are masters to their females, and their Lords:
Then let your will attend on their accords.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adri.
SPEECH.LINE: This ſeruitude makes you to keepe vnwed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luci.
SPEECH.LINE: Not this, but troubles of the marriage bed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: But were you wedded, you wold bear ſome ſway

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Ere I learne loue, Ile practise to obey.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: How if your husband ſtart ſome other where?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Till he come home againe, I would forbeare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: Patience vnmou’d, no maruel though ſhe pause,
They can be meeke, that haue no other cause:
A wretched ſoule bruis’d with aduersitie,
We bid be quiet when we heare it crie.
But were we burdned with like waight of paine,
As much, or more, we ſhould our ſelues complaine:
So thou that hast no vnkinde mate to greeue thee,
With vrging helpeleſſe patience would releeue me;
But if thou liue to ſee like right bereft,
This foole-beg’d patience in thee will be left.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luci.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, I will marry one day but to trie:
Heere comes your man, now is your husband nie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: Say, is your tardie master now at hand?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, hee's at too hands with mee, and that my two eares can witneſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: Say, didst thou ſpeake with him? knowst thou his minde?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: I, I, he told his minde vpon mine eare,
Beshrew his hand, I ſcarce could vnderstand it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Spake hee ſo doubtfully, thou couldst not feele his meaning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, hee ſtrooke ſo plainly, I could too well feele his blowes; and withall ſo doubtfully, that I could ſcarce vnderstand them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adri.
SPEECH.LINE: But ſay, I prethee, is he comming home?
It ſeemes he hath great care to please his wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Why Mistreſſe, ſure my Master is horne mad.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adri.
SPEECH.LINE: Horne mad, thou villaine?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: I meane not Cuckold mad,
But ſure he is ſtarke mad:
When I desir’d him to come home to dinner,
He ask’d me for a hundred markes in gold:
‘Tis dinner time, quoth I: my gold, quoth he:
Your meat doth burne, quoth I: my gold quoth he:
Will you come, quoth I: my gold, quoth he;
Where is the thousand markes I gaue thee villaine?
The Pigge quoth I, is burn’d: my gold, quoth he:
My mistreſſe, ſir, quoth I: hang vp thy Mistreſſe:
I know not thy mistreſſe, out on thy mistreſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luci.
SPEECH.LINE: Quoth who?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Dr.
SPEECH.LINE: Quoth my Master, I know quoth he, no house, no wife, no mistreſſe: ſo that my arrant due vnto my tongue, I thanke him, I bare home vpon my ſhoulders: for in conclusion, he did beat me there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adri.
SPEECH.LINE: Go back againe, thou ſlaue, & fetch him home.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Goe backe againe, and be new beaten home?
For Gods ſake ſend ſome other meſſenger.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adri.
SPEECH.LINE: Backe ſlaue, or I will breake thy pate a-croſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: And he will bleſſe y croſſe with other beating:
Betweene you, I ſhall haue a holy head.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adri.
SPEECH.LINE: Hence prating pesant, fetch thy Master home.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Am I ſo round with you, as you with me,
That like a foot-ball you doe ſpurne me thus:
You ſpurne me hence, and he will ſpurne me hither,
If I last in this ſeruice, you must case me in leather.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luci.
SPEECH.LINE: Fie how impatience lowreth in your face.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adri.
SPEECH.LINE: His company must do his minions grace,
Whil'st I at home ſtarue for a merrie looke:
Hath homelie age th’ alluring beauty tooke
From my poore cheeke? then he hath wasted it.
Are my discourses dull? Barren my wit,
If voluble and ſharpe discourse be mar’d,
Vnkindneſſe blunts it more then marble hard.
Doe their gay vestments his affections baite?
That's not my fault, hee's master of my ſtate.
What ruines are in me that can be found,
By him not ruin’d? Then is he the ground
Of my defeatures. My decayed faire,
A ſunnie looke of his, would ſoone repaire.
But, too vnruly Deere, he breakes the pale,
And feedes from home; poore I am but his ſtale.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luci.
SPEECH.LINE: Selfe-harming Iealousie; fie beat it hence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ad.
SPEECH.LINE: Vnfeeling fools can with ſuch wrongs dispence:
I know his eye doth homage other-where,
Or else, what lets it but he would be here?
Sister, you know he promis’d me a chaine,
Would that alone, a loue he would detaine,
So he would keepe faire quarter with his bed:
I ſee the Iewell best enamaled
Will loose his beautie: yet the gold bides ſtill
That others touch, and often touching will,
Where gold and no man that hath a name,
By falshood and corruption doth it ſhame:
Since that my beautie cannot please his eie,
Ile weepe (what’s left away) and weeping die.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luci.
SPEECH.LINE: How manie fond fooles ſerue mad Ielousie?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: The gold I gaue to Dromio is laid vp
Safe at the Centaur, and the heedfull ſlaue
Is wandred forth in care to ſeeke me out
By computation and mine hosts report.
I could not ſpeake with Dromio, ſince at first
I ſent him from the Mart? ſee here he comes.
How now ſir, is your merrie humor alter’d?
As you loue ſtroakes, ſo iest with me againe:
You know no Centaur? you receiu’d no gold?
Your Mistreſſe ſent to haue me home to dinner?
My house was at the Phœnix? Wast thou mad,
That thus ſo madlie thou did didst answere me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: What anſwer ſir? when ſpake I ſuch a word?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Euen now, euen here, not halfe an howre ſince.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: I did not ſee you ſince you ſent me hence
Home to the Centaur with the gold you gaue me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Villaine, thou didst denie the golds receit,
And toldst me of a Mistreſſe, and a dinner,
For which I hope thou feltst I was displeas’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: I am glad to ſee you in this merrie vaine,
What meanes this iest, I pray you Master tell me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Yea, dost thou ieere & flowt me in the teeth?
Thinkst y I iest? hold, take thou that, & that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dr.
SPEECH.LINE: Hold ſir, for Gods ſake, now your iest is earnest,
Vpon what bargaine do you giue it me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Antiph.
SPEECH.LINE: Because that I familiarlie ſometimes
Doe vse you for my foole, and chat with you,
Your ſawcineſſe will iest vpon my loue,
And make a Common of my ſerious howres,
When the ſunne ſhines, let foolish gnats make ſport,
But creepe in crannies, when he hides his beames:
If you will iest with me, know my aspect,
And fashion your demeanor to my lookes,
Or I will beat this method in your ſconce.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Sconce call you it? ſo you would leaue batte-ring, I had rather haue it a head, and you vse these blows long, I must get a ſconce for my head, and Insconce it to, or else I ſhall ſeek my wit in my ſhoulders, but I pray ſir, why am I beaten?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Dost thou not know?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Nothing ſir, but that I am beaten.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Shall I tell you why?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſir, and wherefore; for they ſay, euery why hath a wherefore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Why first for flowting me, and then wherefore, for vrging it the ſecond time to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Was there euer anie man thus beaten out of ſeason, when in the why and the wherefore, is neither rime nor reason. Well ſir, I thanke you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Thanke me ſir, for what?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry ſir, for this ſomething that you gaue me for nothing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile make you amends next, to giue you nothing for ſomething. But ſay ſir, is it dinner time?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: No ſir, I thinke the meat wants that I haue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: In good time ſir: what’s that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Basting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Well ſir, then 'twill be drie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: If it be ſir, I pray you eat none of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Your reason?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Lest it make you chollericke, and purchase me another drie basting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Well ſir, learne to iest in good time, there's a time for all things.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: I durst haue denied that before you were ſo chollericke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anti.
SPEECH.LINE: By what rule ſir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry ſir, by a rule as plaine as the plaine bald pate of Father time himselfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Let's heare it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: There's no time for a man to recouer his haire that growes bald by nature.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: May he not doe it by fine and recouerie?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes, to pay a fine for a perewig, and recouer the lost haire of another man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, is Time ſuch a niggard of haire, being (as it is) ſo plentifull an excrement?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Because it is a bleſſing that hee bestowes on beasts, and what he hath ſcanted them in haire, hee hath giuen them in wit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, but theres manie a man hath more haire then wit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Not a man of those but he hath the wit to lose his haire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Why thou didst conclude hairy men plain dea-lers without wit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: The plainer dealer, the ſooner lost; yet he loo-seth it in a kinde of iollitie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: For what reason.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: For two, and ſound ones to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay not ſound I pray you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Sure ones then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, not ſure in a thing falsing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Certaine ones then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: Name them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: The one to ſaue the money that he ſpends in trying: the other, that at dinner they ſhould not drop in his porrage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: You would all this time haue prou’d, there is no time for all things.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry and did ſir: namely, in no time to re-couer haire lost by Nature.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: But your reason was not ſubstantiall, why there is no time to recouer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Thus I mend it: Time himselfe is bald, and therefore to the worlds end, will haue bald followers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: I knew 'twould be a bald conclusion: but ſoft, who wafts vs yonder.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adri.
SPEECH.LINE: I, I, Antipholus, looke ſtrange and frowne,
Some other Mistreſſe hath thy ſweet aspects:
I am not Adriana, nor thy wife.
The time was once, when thou vn-vrg’d wouldst vow,
That neuer words were musicke to thine eare,
That neuer obiect pleasing in thine eye,
That neuer touch well welcome to thy hand,
That neuer meat ſweet-sauour’d in thy taste,
Vnleſſe I ſpake, or look’d, or touch’d, or caru’d to thee.
How comes it now, my Husband, oh how comes it,
That thou art then estranged from thy ſelfe?
Thy ſelfe I call it, being ſtrange to me:
That vndiuidable Incorporate
Am better then thy deere ſelfes better part.
Ah doe not teare away thy ſelfe from me;
For know my loue: as easie maist thou fall
A drop of water in the breaking gulfe,
And take vnmingled thence that drop againe
Without addition or diminishing,
As take from me thy ſelfe, and not me too.
How deerely would it touch thee to the quicke,
Shouldst thou but heare I were licencious?
And that this body consecrate to thee,
By Ruffian Lust ſhould be contaminate?
Wouldst thou not ſpit at me, and ſpurne at me,
And hurle the name of husband in my face,
And teare the ſtain’d ſkin of my Harlot brow,
And from my false hand cut the wedding ring,
And breake it with a deepe-diuorcing vow?
I know thou canst, and therefore ſee thou doe it.
I am poſſest with an adulterate blot,
My bloud is mingled with the crime of lust:
For if we two be one, and thou play false,
I doe digest the poison of thy flesh,
Being ſtrumpeted by thy contagion:
Keepe then faire league and truce with thy true bed,
I liue distain’d, thou vndishonoured.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Antip.
SPEECH.LINE: Plead you to me faire dame? I know you not:
In Ephesus I am but two houres old,
As ſtrange vnto your towne, as to your talke,
Who euery word by all my wit being ſcan’d,
Wants wit in all, one word to vnderstand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luci.
SPEECH.LINE: Fie brother, how the world is chang’d with you:
When were you wont to vse my ſister thus?
She ſent for you by Dromio home to dinner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: By Dromio?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Drom.
SPEECH.LINE: By me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: By thee, and this thou didst returne from him.
That he did buffet thee, and in his blowes,
Denied my house for his, me for his wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Did you conuerse ſir with this gentlewoman:
What is the course and drift of your compact?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſir? I neuer ſaw her till this time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Villaine thou liest, for euen her verie words,
Didst thou deliuer to me on the Mart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: I neuer ſpake with her in all my life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: How can ſhe thus then call vs by our names?
Vnleſſe it be by inspiration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adri.
SPEECH.LINE: How ill agrees it with your grauitie,
To counterfeit thus grosely with your ſlaue,
Abetting him to thwart me in my moode;
Be it my wrong, you are from me exempt,
But wrong not that wrong with a more contempt.
Come I will fasten on this ſleeue of thine:
Thou art an Elme my husband, I a Vine:
Whose weakneſſe married to thy ſtranger ſtate,
Makes me with thy ſtrength to communicate:
If ought poſſeſſe thee from me, it is droſſe,
Vsurping Iuie, Brier, or idle Moſſe,
Who all for want of pruning, with intrusion,
Infect thy ſap, and liue on thy confusion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: To mee ſhee ſpeakes, ſhee moues mee for her theame; What, was I married to her in my dreame? Or ſleepe I now, and thinke I heare all this? What error driues our eies and eares amiſſe? Vntill I know this ſure vncertaintie, Ile entertaine the free’d fallacie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Dromio, goe bid the ſeruants ſpred for dinner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh for my beads, I croſſe me for a ſinner.
This is the Fairie land, oh ſpight of ſpights,
We talke with Goblins, Owles and Sprights;
If we obay them not, this will insue:
They'll ſucke our breath, or pinch vs blacke and blew.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Why prat'st thou to thy ſelfe, and anſwer'st not?
Dromio, thou Dromio, thou ſnaile, thou ſlug, thou ſot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: I am transformed Master, am I not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke thou art in minde, and ſo am I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay Master, both in minde, and in my ſhape.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou hast thine owne forme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: No, I am an Ape.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: If thou art chang’d to ought, ‘tis to an Aſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis true ſhe rides me, and I long for graſſe.
‘Tis ſo, I am an Aſſe, else it could neuer be,
But I ſhould know her as well as ſhe knowes me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come, no longer will I be a foole,
To put the finger in the eie and weepe;
Whil'st man and Master laughes my wœs to ſcorne:
Come ſir to dinner, Dromio keepe the gate:
Husband Ile dine aboue with you to day,
And ſhriue you of a thousand idle prankes:
Sirra, if any aske you for your Master,
Say he dines forth, and let no creature enter:
Come ſister, Dromio play the Porter well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Am I in earth, in heauen, or in hell?
Sleeping or waking, mad or well aduisde:
Knowne vnto these, and to my ſelfe disguisde:
Ile ſay as they ſay, and perseuer ſo:
And in this mist at all aduentures go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Master, ſhall I be Porter at the gate?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: I, and let none enter, least I breake your pate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come, Antipholus, we dine to late.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Antipholus of Ephesus, his man Dromio, Angelo the Goldsmith, and Balthaser the Merchant

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Anti.
SPEECH.LINE: Good ſignior Angelo you must excuse vs all,
My wife is ſhrewish when I keepe not howres;
Say that I lingerd with you at your ſhop
To ſee the making of her Carkanet,
And that to morrow you will bring it home.
But here's a villaine that would face me downe
He met me on the Mart, and that I beat him,
And charg’d him with a thousand markes in gold,
And that I did denie my wife and house;
Thou drunkard thou, what didst thou meane by this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Say what you wil ſir, but I know what I know,
That you beat me at the Mart I haue your hand to ſhow;
If y ſkin were parchment, & y blows you gaue were ink,
Your owne hand-writing would tell you what I thinke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke thou art an aſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry ſo it doth appeare
By the wrongs I ſuffer, and the blowes I beare,
I ſhould kicke being kickt, and being at that paſſe,
You would keepe from my heeles, and beware of an aſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.An.
SPEECH.LINE: Y'are ſad ſignior Balthazar, pray God our cheer
May anſwer my good will, and your good welcom here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bal.
SPEECH.LINE: I hold your dainties cheap ſir, & your welcom deer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.An.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh ſignior Balthazar, either at flesh or fish,
A table full of welcome, makes ſcarce one dainty dish.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bal.
SPEECH.LINE: Good meat ſir is co[m]mon that euery churle affords.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anti.
SPEECH.LINE: And welcome more common, for thats nothing but words.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bal.
SPEECH.LINE: Small cheere and great welcome, makes a mer-rie feast.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anti.
SPEECH.LINE: I, to a niggardly Host, and more ſparing guest:
But though my cates be meane, take them in good part,
Better cheere may you haue, but not with better hart.
But ſoft, my doore is lockt; goe bid them let vs in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Maud, Briget, Marian, Cisley, Gillian, Ginn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Mome, Malthorse, Capon, Coxcombe, Idi-ot,
Patch,
Either get thee from the dore, or ſit downe at the hatch:
Dost thou coniure for wenches, that y calst for ſuch ſtore,
When one is one too many, goe get thee from the dore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: What patch is made our Porter? my Master ſtayes in the ſtreet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Let him walke from whence he came, lest hee catch cold on's feet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Who talks within there? hoa, open the dore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Right ſir, Ile tell you when, and you'll tell me wherefore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Wherefore? for my dinner: I haue not din’d to day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Nor to day here you must not come againe when you may.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anti.
SPEECH.LINE: What art thou that keep'st mee out from the howse I owe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: The Porter for this time Sir, and my name is
Dromio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: O villaine, thou hast ſtolne both mine office and my name, The one nere got me credit, the other mickle blame: If thou hadst beene Dromio to day in my place, Thou wouldst haue chang’d thy face for a name, or thy name for an aſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luce.
SPEECH.LINE: What a coile is there Dromio? who are those at the gate?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Let my Master in Luce.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luce.
SPEECH.LINE: Faith no, hee comes too late, and ſo tell your
Master.

SCENE.SPEECH: E.Dro. O Lord I must laugh, haue at you with a Pro-uerbe, _ Shall I ſet in my ſtaffe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luce.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue at you with another, that’s when? can you tell?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: If thy name be called Luce, Luce thou hast an-swer’d him well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anti.
SPEECH.LINE: Doe you heare you minion, you'll let vs in I hope?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luce.
SPEECH.LINE: I thought to haue askt you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: And you ſaid no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: So come helpe, well ſtrooke, there was blow for blow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anti.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou baggage let me in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luce.
SPEECH.LINE: Can you tell for whose ſake?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Drom.
SPEECH.LINE: Master, knocke the doore hard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luce.
SPEECH.LINE: Let him knocke till it ake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anti.
SPEECH.LINE: You'll crie for this minion, if I beat the doore downe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luce.
SPEECH.LINE: What needs all that, and a paire of ſtocks in the towne?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: Who is that at the doore y keeps all this noise?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: By my troth your towne is troubled with vn-ruly boies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anti.
SPEECH.LINE: Are you there Wife? you might haue come before.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adri.
SPEECH.LINE: Your wife ſir knaue? go get you from the dore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: If you went in paine Master, this knaue wold goe ſore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Angelo.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere is neither cheere ſir, nor welcome, we would faine haue either.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baltz.
SPEECH.LINE: In debating which was best, wee ſhall part with neither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: They ſtand at the doore, Master, bid them welcome hither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anti.
SPEECH.LINE: There is ſomething in the winde, that we can-not get in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: You would ſay ſo Master, if your garments were thin. Your cake here is warme within: you ſtand here in the cold. It would make a man mad as a Bucke to be ſo bought and ſold.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Go fetch me ſomething, Ile break ope the gate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Breake any breaking here, and Ile breake your knaues pate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: A man may breake a word with your ſir, and words are but winde: I and breake it in your face, ſo he break it not behinde.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: It ſeemes thou want'st breaking, out vpon thee hinde.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Here's too much out vpon thee, I pray thee let me in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: I, when fowles haue no feathers, and fish haue no fin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, Ile breake in: go borrow me a crow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: A crow without feather, Master meane you ſo;
For a fish without a finne, ther's a fowle without a fether,
If a crow help vs in ſirra, wee'll plucke a crow together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Go, get thee gon, fetch me an iron Crow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Balth.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue patience ſir, oh let it not be ſo,
Heerein you warre against your reputation,
And draw within the compaſſe of ſuspect
Th’ vnuiolated honor of your wife.
Once this your long experience of your wisedome,
Her ſober vertue, yeares, and modestie,
Plead on your part ſome cause to you vnknowne;
And doubt not ſir, but ſhe will well excuse
Why at this time the dores are made against you.
Be rul’d by me, depart in patience,
And let vs to the Tyger all to dinner,
And about euening come your ſelfe alone,
To know the reason of this ſtrange restraint:
If by ſtrong hand you offer to breake in
Now in the ſtirring paſſage of the day,
A vulgar comment will be made of it;
And that ſupposed by the common rowt
Against your yet vngalled estimation,
That may with foule intrusion enter in,
And dwell vpon your graue when you are dead;
For ſlander liues vpon ſucceſſion:
For euer hows’d, where it gets poſſeſſion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anti.
SPEECH.LINE: You haue preuail’d, I will depart in quiet,
And in despight of mirth meane to be merrie:
I know a wench of excellent discourse,
Prettie and wittie; wilde, and yet too gentle;
There will we dine: this woman that I meane
My wife (but I protest without desert)
Hath oftentimes vpbraided me withall:
To her will we to dinner, get you home
And fetch the chaine, by this I know ‘tis made,
Bring it I pray you to the Porpentine,
For there's the house: That chaine will I bestow
(Be it for nothing but to ſpight my wife)
Vpon mine hosteſſe there, good ſir make haste:
Since mine owne doores refuse to entertaine me,
Ile knocke else-where, to ſee if they'll disdaine me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile meet you at that place ſome houre hence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anti.
SPEECH.LINE: Do ſo, this iest ſhall cost me ſome expence.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Iuliana, with Antipholus of Siracusia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iulia.
SPEECH.LINE: And may it be that you haue quite forgot
A husbands office? ſhall Antipholus
Euen in the ſpring of Loue, thy Loue-springs rot?
Shall loue in buildings grow ſo ruinate?
If you did wed my ſister for her wealth,
Then for her wealths-sake vse her with more kindneſſe:
Or if you like else-where doe it by ſtealth,
Muffle your false loue with ſome ſhew of blindneſſe:
Let not my ſister read it in your eye:
Be not thy tongue thy owne ſhames Orator:
Looke ſweet, ſpeake faire, become disloyaltie:
Apparell vice like vertues harbenger:
Beare a faire presence, though your heart be tainted,
Teach ſinne the carriage of a holy Saint,
Be ſecret false: what need ſhe be acquainted?
What ſimple thiefe brags of his owne attaine?
‘Tis double wrong to truant with your bed,
And let her read it in thy lookes at boord:
Shame hath a bastard fame, well managed,
Ill deeds is doubled with an euill word:
Alas poore women, make vs not beleeue
(Being compact of credit) that you loue vs,
Though others haue the arme, ſhew vs the ſleeue:
We in your motion turne, and you may moue vs.
Then gentle brother get you in againe;
Comfort my ſister, cheere her, call her wise;
‘Tis holy ſport to be a little vaine,
When the ſweet breath of flatterie conquers ſtrife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Anti.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweete Mistris, what your name is else I know not; Nor by what wonder you do hit of mine: Leſſe in your knowledge, and your grace you ſhow not, Then our earths wonder, more then earth diuine. Teach me deere creature how to thinke and ſpeake: Lay open to my earthie groſſe conceit: Smothred in errors, feeble, ſhallow, weake, The foulded meaning of your words deceit: Against my ſoules pure truth, why labour you, To make it wander in an vnknowne field? Are you a god? would you create me new? Transforme me then, and to your powre Ile yeeld. But if that I am I, then well I know, Your weeping ſister is no wife of mine, Nor to her bed no homage doe I owe: Farre more, farre more, to you doe I decline: Oh traine me not ſweet Mermaide with thy note, To drowne me in thy ſister floud of teares: Sing Siren for thy ſelfe, and I will dote: Spread ore the ſiluer waues thy golden haires; And as a bud Ile take thee, and there lie: And in that glorious ſupposition thinke, He gaines by death, that hath ſuch meanes to die: Let Loue, being light, be drowned if ſhe ſinke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: What are you mad, that you doe reason ſo?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Not mad, but mated, how I doe not know.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: It is a fault that ſpringeth from your eie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: For gazing on your beames faire ſun being by.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Gaze when you ſhould, and that will cleere your ſight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: As good to winke ſweet loue, as looke on night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Why call you me loue? Call my ſister ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Thy ſisters ſister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: That's my ſister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: No: it is thy ſelfe, mine owne ſelfes better part:
Mine eies cleere eie, my deere hearts deerer heart;
My foode, my fortune, and my ſweet hopes aime;
My ſole earths heauen, and my heauens claime.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: All this my ſister is, or else ſhould be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Call thy ſelfe ſister ſweet, for I am thee:
Thee will I loue, and with thee lead my life;
Thou hast no husband yet, nor I no wife:
Giue me thy hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh ſoft ſir, hold you ſtill:
Ile fetch my ſister to get her good will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Why how now Dromio, where run'st thou ſo fast?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Doe you know me ſir? Am I Dromio? Am I your man? Am I my ſelfe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou art Dromio, thou art my man, thou art thy ſelfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: I am an aſſe, I am a womans man, and besides my ſelfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: What womans man? and how besides thy ſelfe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Marrie ſir, besides my ſelfe, I am due to a woman: One that claimes me, one that haunts me, one that will haue me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anti.
SPEECH.LINE: What claime laies ſhe to thee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry ſir, ſuch claime as you would lay to your horse, and ſhe would haue me as a beast, not that I bee-ing a beast ſhe would haue me, but that ſhe being a ve-rie beastly creature layes claime to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anti.
SPEECH.LINE: What is ſhe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: A very reuerent body: I ſuch a one, as a man may not ſpeake of, without he ſay ſir reuerence, I haue but leane lucke in the match, and yet is ſhe a wondrous fat marriage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anti.
SPEECH.LINE: How dost thou meane a fat marriage?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry ſir, ſhe's the Kitchin wench, & al grease, and I know not what vse to put her too, but to make a Lampe of her, and run from her by her owne light. I warrant, her ragges and the Tallow in them, will burne a Poland Winter: If ſhe liues till doomesday, ſhe'l burne a weeke longer then the whole World.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anti.
SPEECH.LINE: What complexion is ſhe of?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Swart like my ſhoo, but her face nothing like ſo cleane kept: for why? ſhe ſweats a man may goe o-uer-shoœs in the grime of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anti.
SPEECH.LINE: That's a fault that water will mend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: No ſir, ‘tis in graine, Noahs flood could not do it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anti.
SPEECH.LINE: What's her name?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Nell Sir: but her name is three quarters, that’s an Ell and three quarters, will not measure her from hip to hip.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anti.
SPEECH.LINE: Then ſhe beares ſome bredth?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: No longer from head to foot, then from hippe to hippe: ſhe is ſphericall, like a globe: I could find out Countries in her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anti.
SPEECH.LINE: In what part of her body ſtands Ireland?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry ſir in her buttockes, I found it out by the bogges.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Where Scotland?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: I found it by the barrenneſſe, hard in the palme of the hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Where France?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: In her forhead, arm’d and reuerted, making warre against her heire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Where England?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: I look’d for the chalkle Cliffes, but I could find no whiteneſſe in them. But I gueſſe, it ſtood in her chin by the ſalt rheume that ranne betweene France, and it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Where Spaine?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Faith I ſaw it not: but I felt it hot in her breth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Where America, the Indies?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh ſir, vpon her nose, all ore embellished with Rubies, Carbuncles, Saphires, declining their rich As-pect to the hot breath of Spaine, who ſent whole Ar-madœs of Carrects to be ballast at her nose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anti.
SPEECH.LINE: Where ſtood Belgia, the Netherlands?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh ſir, I did not looke ſo low. To conclude, this drudge or Diuiner layd claime to mee, call’d mee Dromio, ſwore I was aſſur’d to her, told me what priuie markes I had about mee, as the marke of my ſhoulder, the Mole in my necke, the great Wart on my left arme, that I amaz’d ranne from her as a witch. And I thinke, if my brest had not beene made of faith, and my heart of ſteele, ſhe had transform’d me to a Curtull dog, & made me turne i'th wheele.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anti.
SPEECH.LINE: Go hie thee presently, post to the rode,
And if the winde blow any way from ſhore,
I will not harbour in this Towne to night.
If any Barke put forth, come to the Mart,
Where I will walke till thou returne to me:
If euerie one knowes vs, and we know none,
‘Tis time I thinke to trudge, packe, and be gone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: As from a Beare a man would run for life,
So flie I from her that would be my wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anti.
SPEECH.LINE: There's none but Witches do inhabite heere,
And therefore ‘tis hie time that I were hence:
She that doth call me husband, euen my ſoule
Doth for a wife abhorre. But her faire ſister
Poſſest with ſuch a gentle ſoueraigne grace,
Of ſuch inchanting presence and discourse,
Hath almost made me Traitor to my ſelfe:
But least my ſelfe be guilty to ſelfe wrong,
Ile ſtop mine eares against the Mermaids ſong.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Mr Antipholus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anti.
SPEECH.LINE: I that’s my name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: I know it well ſir, lœ here's the chaine,
I thought to haue tane you at the Porpentine,
The chaine vnfinish’d made me ſtay thus long.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anti.
SPEECH.LINE: What is your will that I ſhal do with this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: What please your ſelfe ſir: I haue made it for you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anti.
SPEECH.LINE: Made it for me ſir, I bespoke it not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Not once, nor twice, but twentie times you haue: Go home with it, and please your Wife withall, And ſoone at ſupper time Ile visit you, And then receiue my money for the chaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anti.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you ſir receiue the money now.
For feare you ne're ſee chaine, nor mony more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang
SPEECH.LINE: You are a merry man ſir, fare you well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: What I ſhould thinke of this, I cannot tell:
But this I thinke, there's no man is ſo vaine,
That would refuse ſo faire an offer’d Chaine.
I ſee a man heere needs not liue by ſhifts,
When in the ſtreets he meetes ſuch Golden gifts:
Ile to the Mart, and there for Dromio ſtay,
If any ſhip put out, then ſtraight away.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter a Merchant, Goldsmith, and an Officer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: You know ſince Pentecost the ſum is due,
And ſince I haue not much importun’d you,
Nor now I had not, but that I am bound
To Persia, and want Gilders for my voyage:
Therefore make present ſatisfaction,
Or Ile attach you by this Officer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gold.
SPEECH.LINE: Euen iust the ſum that I do owe to you,
Is growing to me by Antipholus,
And in the instant that I met with you,
He had of me a Chaine, at fiue a clocke
I ſhall receiue the money for the ſame:
Pleaseth you walke with me downe to his house,
I will discharge my bond, and thanke you too.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Antipholus Ephes. Dromio from the Courtizans.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Offi.
SPEECH.LINE: That labour may you ſaue: See where he comes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: While I go to the Goldsmiths house, go thou
And buy a ropes end, that will I bestow
Among my wife, and their confederates,
For locking me out of my doores by day:
But ſoft I ſee the Goldsmith; get thee gone,
Buy thou a rope, and bring it home to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: I buy a thousand pound a yeare, I buy a rope.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eph.Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: A man is well holpe vp that trusts to you,
I promised your presence, and the Chaine,
But neither Chaine nor Goldsmith came to me:
Belike you thought our loue would last too long
If it were chain’d together: and therefore came not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gold.
SPEECH.LINE: Sauing your merrie humor: here's the note
How much your Chaine weighs to the vtmost charect,
The fineneſſe of the Gold, and chargefull fashion,
Which doth amount to three odde Duckets more
Then I ſtand debted to this Gentleman,
I pray you ſee him presently discharg’d,
For he is bound to Sea, and ſtayes but for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anti.
SPEECH.LINE: I am not furnish’d with the present monie:
Besides I haue ſome busineſſe in the towne,
Good Signior take the ſtranger to my house,
And with you take the Chaine, and bid my wife
Disburse the ſumme, on the receit thereof,
Perchance I will be there as ſoone as you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gold.
SPEECH.LINE: Then you will bring the Chaine to her your ſelfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anti.
SPEECH.LINE: No beare it with you, least I come not time e-nough.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gold.
SPEECH.LINE: Well ſir, I will? Haue you the Chaine about you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: And if I haue not ſir, I hope you haue:
Or else you may returne without your money.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gold.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay come I pray you ſir, giue me the Chaine:
Both winde and tide ſtayes for this Gentleman,
And I too blame haue held him heere too long.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anti.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Lord, you vse this dalliance to excuse
Your breach of promise to the Porpentine,
I ſhould haue chid you for not bringing it,
But like a ſhrew you first begin to brawle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: The houre ſteales on, I pray you ſir dispatch.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gold.
SPEECH.LINE: You heare how he importunes me, the Chaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Why giue it to my wife, and fetch your mony.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gold.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come, you know I gaue it you euen now.
Either ſend the Chaine, or ſend me by ſome token.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Fie, now you run this humor out of breath,
Come where's the Chaine, I pray you let me ſee it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: My busineſſe cannot brooke this dalliance,
Good ſir ſay, whe'r you'l anſwer me, or no:
If not, Ile leaue him to the Officer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: I anſwer you? What ſhould I anſwer you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gold.
SPEECH.LINE: The monie that you owe me for the Chaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: I owe you none, till I receiue the Chaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gold.
SPEECH.LINE: You know I gaue it you halfe an houre ſince.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: You gaue me none, you wrong mee much to ſay ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gold.
SPEECH.LINE: You wrong me more ſir in denying it.
Consider how it ſtands vpon my credit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Well Officer, arrest him at my ſuite.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Offi.
SPEECH.LINE: I do, and charge you in the Dukes name to o-bey me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gold.
SPEECH.LINE: This touches me in reputation.
Either consent to pay this ſum for me,
Or I attach you by this Officer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Consent to pay thee that I neuer had:
Arrest me foolish fellow if thou dar'st.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gold.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere is thy fee, arrest him Officer.
I would not ſpare my brother in this case,
If he ſhould ſcorne me ſo apparantly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Offic.
SPEECH.LINE: I do arrest you ſir, you heare the ſuite.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: I do obey thee, till I giue thee baile.
But ſirrah, you ſhall buy this ſport as deere,
As all the mettall in your ſhop will anſwer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gold.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, ſir, I ſhall haue Law in Ephesus,
To your notorious ſhame, I doubt it not.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Dromio Sira. from the Bay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Master, there's a Barke of Epidamium,
That ſtaies but till her Owner comes aboord,
And then ſir ſhe beares away. Our fraughtage ſir,
I haue conuei’d aboord, and I haue bought
The Oyle, the Balsamum, and Aqua-vitae.
The ſhip is in her trim, the merrie winde
Blowes faire from land: they ſtay for nought at all,
But for their Owner, Master, and your ſelfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: How now? a Madman? Why thou peeuish ſheep
What ſhip of Epidamium ſtaies for me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: A ſhip you ſent me too, to hier waftage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou drunken ſlaue, I ſent thee for a rope,
And told thee to what purpose, and what end.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſent me for a ropes end as ſoone,
You ſent me to the Bay ſir, for a Barke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: I will debate this matter at more leisure
And teach your eares to list me with more heede:
To Adriana Villaine hie thee ſtraight:
Giue her this key, and tell her in the Deske
That's couer’d o’re with Turkish Tapistrie,
There is a purse of Duckets, let her ſend it:
Tell her, I am arrested in the ſtreete,
And that ſhall baile me: hie thee ſlaue, be gone,
On Officer to prison, till it come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dromio.
SPEECH.LINE: To Adriana, that is where we din’d,
Where Dowsabell did claime me for her husband,
She is too bigge I hope for me to compaſſe,
Thither I must, although against my will:
For ſeruants must their Masters mindes fulfill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: Ah Luciana, did he tempt thee ſo?
Might'st thou perceiue austeerely in his eie,
That he did plead in earnest, yea or no:
Look’d he or red or pale, or ſad or merrily?
What obseruation mad'st thou in this case?
Oh, his hearts Meteors tilting in his face.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: First he deni’de you had in him no right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: He meant he did me none: the more my ſpight

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Then ſwore he that he was a ſtranger heere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: And true he ſwore, though yet forsworne hee were.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Then pleaded I for you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: And what ſaid he?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: That loue I begg’d for you, he begg’d of me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: With what perswasion did he tempt thy loue?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: With words, that in an honeſt ſuit might moue.
First, he did praise my beautie, then my ſpeech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: Did'st ſpeake him faire?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue patience I beseech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: I cannot, nor I will not hold me ſtill.
My tongue, though not my heart, ſhall haue his will.
He is deformed, crooked, old, and ſere,
Ill-fac’d, worse bodied, ſhapeleſſe euery where:
Vicious, vngentle, foolish, blunt, vnkinde,
Stigmaticall in making worse in minde.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Who would be iealous then of ſuch a one?
No euill lost is wail’d, when it is gone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: Ah but I thinke him better then I ſay:
And yet would herein others eies were worse:
Farre from her nest the Lapwing cries away;
My heart praies for him, though my tongue doe curse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Here goe: the deske, the purse, ſweet now make haste.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: How hast thou lost thy breath?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: By running fast.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: Where is thy Master Dromio? Is he well?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: No, he's in Tartar limbo, worse then hell:
A diuell in an euerlasting garment hath him;
On whose hard heart is button’d vp with ſteele:
A Feind, a Fairie, pittileſſe and ruffe:
A Wolfe, nay worse, a fellow all in buffe:
A back friend, a ſhoulder-clapper, one that counterma[n]ds
The paſſages of allies, creekes, and narrow lands:
A hound that runs Counter, and yet draws drifoot well,
One that before the Iudgme[n]t carries poore ſoules to hel.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: Why man, what is the matter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: I doe not know the matter, hee is rested on the case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: What is he arrested? tell me at whose ſuite?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: I know not at whose ſuite he is arested well; but is in a ſuite of buffe which rested him, that can I tell, will you ſend him Mistris redemption, the monie in his deske.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: Go fetch it Sister: this I wonder at.
Thus he vnknowne to me ſhould be in debt:
Tell me, was he arested on a band?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Not on a band, but on a ſtronger thing:
A chaine, a chaine, doe you not here it ring.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adria.
SPEECH.LINE: What, the chaine?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: No, no, the bell, ‘tis time that I were gone:
It was two ere I left him, and now the clocke ſtrikes one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: The houres come backe, that did I neuer here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh yes, if any houre meete a Serieant, a turnes backe for verie feare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adri.
SPEECH.LINE: As if time were in debt: how fondly do'st thou reason?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Time is a verie bankerout, and owes more then he's worth to ſeason. Nay, he's a theefe too: haue you not heard men ſay, That time comes ſtealing on by night and day? If I be in debt and theft, and a Serieant in the way, Hath he not reason to turne backe an houre in a day?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: Go Dromio, there's the monie, beare it ſtraight,
And bring thy Master home imediately.
Come ſister, I am prest downe with conceit:
Conceit, my comfort and my iniurie. Exit.
There's not a man I meete but doth ſalute me
As if I were their well acquainted friend,
And euerie one doth call me by my name:
Some tender monie to me, ſome inuite me;
Some other giue me thankes for kindneſſes;
Some offer me Commodities to buy.
Euen now a tailor cal’d me in his ſhop,
And ſhow’d me Silkes that he had bought for me,
And therewithall tooke measure of my body.
Sure these are but imaginarie wiles,
And lapland Sorcerers inhabite here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Master, here's the gold you ſent me for: what haue you got the picture of old Adam new apparel’d?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: What gold is this? What Adam do'st thou meane?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Not that Adam that kept the Paradise: but that Adam that keepes the prison; hee that goes in the calues-skin, that was kil’d for the Prodigall: hee that came behinde you ſir, like an euill angel, and bid you for-sake your libertie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: I vnderstand thee not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: No? why ‘tis a plaine case: he that went like a Base-Viole in a case of leather; the man ſir, that when gentlemen are tired giues them a ſob, and rests them: he ſir, that takes pittie on decaied men, and giues them ſuites of durance: he that ſets vp his rest to doe more ex-ploits with his Mace, then a Moris Pike.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: What thou mean'st an officer?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſir, the Serieant of the Band: he that brings any man to anſwer it that breakes his Band: one that thinkes a man alwaies going to bed, and ſaies, God giue you good rest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Well ſir, there rest in your foolerie:
Is there any ſhips puts forth to night? may we be gone?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ſir, I brought you word an houre ſince, that the Barke Expedition put forth to night, and then were you hindred by the Serieant to tarry for the Hoy Delay: Here are the angels that you ſent for to deliuer you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: The fellow is distract, and ſo am I,
And here we wander in illusions:
Some bleſſed power deliuer vs from hence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cur.
SPEECH.LINE: Well met, well met, Master Antipholus:
I ſee ſir you haue found the Gold-smith now:
Is that the chaine you promis’d me to day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Sathan auoide, I charge thee tempt me not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Master, is this Mistris Sathan?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: It is the diuell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, ſhe is worse, ſhe is the diuels dam: And here ſhe comes in the habit of a light wench, and thereof comes, that the wenches ſay God dam me, That's as much to ſay, God make me a light wench: It is writ-ten, they appeare to men like angels of light, light is an effect of fire, and fire will burne: ergo, light wenches will burne, come not neere her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cur.
SPEECH.LINE: Your man and you are maruailous merrie ſir.
Will you goe with me, wee'll mend our dinner here?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Master, if do expect ſpoon-meate, or bespeake a long ſpoone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Why Dromio?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Marrie he must haue a long ſpoone that must eate with the diuell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Auoid then fiend, what tel'st thou me of ſupping?
Thou art, as you are all a ſorcereſſe:
I coniure thee to leaue me, and be gon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cur.
SPEECH.LINE: Giue me the ring of mine you had at dinner,
Or for my Diamond the Chaine you promis’d,
And Ile be gone ſir, and not trouble you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Some diuels aske but the parings of ones naile, a rush, a haire, a drop of blood, a pin, a nut, a cherrie-stone: but ſhe more couetous, wold haue a chaine: Ma-ster be wise, and if you giue it her, the diuell will ſhake her Chaine, and fright vs with it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cur.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you ſir my Ring, or else the Chaine,
I hope you do not meane to cheate me ſo?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Auant thou witch: Come Dromio let vs go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Flie pride ſaies the Pea-cocke, Mistris that you know.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cur.
SPEECH.LINE: Now out of doubt Antipholus is mad,
Else would he neuer ſo demeane himselfe,
A Ring he hath of mine worth fortie Duckets,
And for the ſame he promis’d me a Chaine,
Both one and other he denies me now:
The reason that I gather he is mad,
Besides this present instance of his rage,
Is a mad tale he told to day at dinner,
Of his owne doores being ſhut against his entrance.
Belike his wife acquainted with his fits,
On purpose ſhut the doores against his way:
My way is now to hie home to his house,
And tell his wife, that being Lunaticke,
He rush’d into my house, and tooke perforce
My Ring away. This course I fittest choose,
For fortie Duckets is too much to loose.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Antipholus Ephes. with a Iailor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: Feare me not man, I will not breake away,
Ile giue thee ere I leaue thee ſo much money
To warrant thee as I am rested for.
My wife is in a wayward moode to day,
And will not lightly trust the Meſſenger,
That I ſhould be attach’d in Ephesus,
I tell you 'twill ſound harshly in her eares.

LINE.STAGEDIR: Enter Dromio Eph. with a ropes end.

SPEECH.LINE: Heere comes my Man, I thinke he brings the monie.
How now ſir? Haue you that I ſent you for?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Here's that I warrant you will pay them all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anti.
SPEECH.LINE: But where's the Money?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ſir, I gaue the Monie for the Rope.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Fiue hundred Duckets villaine for a rope?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile ſerue you ſir fiue hundred at the rate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: To what end did I bid thee hie thee home?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: To a ropes end ſir, and to that end am I re-turn’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: And to that end ſir, I will welcome you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Offi.
SPEECH.LINE: Good ſir be patient.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay ‘tis for me to be patient, I am in aduer-sitie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Offi.
SPEECH.LINE: Good now hold thy tongue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, rather perswade him to hold his hands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anti.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou whoreson ſenseleſſe Villaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: I would I were ſenseleſſe ſir, that I might not feele your blowes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anti.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou art ſensible in nothing but blowes, and ſo is an Aſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: I am an Aſſe indeede, you may prooue it by my long eares. I haue ſerued him from the houre of my Natiuitie to this instant, and haue nothing at his hands for my ſeruice but blowes. When I am cold, he heates me with beating: when I am warme, he cooles me with beating: I am wak’d with it when I ſleepe, rais’d with it when I ſit, driuen out of doores with it when I goe from home, welcom’d home with it when I returne, nay I beare it on my ſhoulders, as a begger woont her brat: and I thinke when he hath lam’d me, I ſhall begge with it from doore to doore.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Adriana, Luciana, Courtizan, and a Schoole-master, call’d Pinch

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Come goe along, my wife is comming yon-der.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Mistris respice finem, respect your end, or ra-ther the prophesie like the Parrat, beware the ropes end.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anti
SPEECH.LINE: Wilt thou ſtill talke?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Curt.
SPEECH.LINE: How ſay you now? Is not your husband mad?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adri.
SPEECH.LINE: His inciuility confirmes no leſſe:
Good Doctor Pinch, you are a Coniurer,
Establish him in his true ſence againe,
And I will please you what you will demand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas how fiery, and how ſharpe he lookes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cur.
SPEECH.LINE: Marke, how he trembles in his extasie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pinch.
SPEECH.LINE: Giue me your hand, and let mee feele your pulse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: There is my hand, and let it feele your eare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pinch.
SPEECH.LINE: I charge thee Sathan, hous’d within this man,
To yeeld poſſeſſion to my holie praiers,
And to thy ſtate of darkneſſe hie thee ſtraight,
I coniure thee by all the Saints in heauen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anti.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace doting wizard, peace; I am not mad.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh that thou wer't not, poore distreſſed ſoule.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anti.
SPEECH.LINE: You Minion you, are these your Customers?
Did this Companion with the ſaffron face
Reuell and feast it at my house to day,
Whil'st vpon me the guiltie doores were ſhut,
And I denied to enter in my house.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: O husband, God doth know you din’d at home
Where would you had remain’d vntill this time,
Free from these ſlanders, and this open ſhame.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anti.
SPEECH.LINE: Din’d at home? Thou Villaine, what ſayest thou?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir ſooth to ſay, you did not dine at home.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Were not my doores lockt vp, and I ſhut out?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Perdie, your doores were lockt, and you ſhut out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anti.
SPEECH.LINE: And did not ſhe her ſelfe reuile me there?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Sans Fable, ſhe her ſelfe reuil’d you there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anti.
SPEECH.LINE: Did not her Kitchen maide raile, taunt, and ſcorne me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Certis ſhe did, the kitchin vestall ſcorn’d you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: And did not I in rage depart from thence?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: In veritie you did, my bones beares witneſſe,
That ſince haue felt the vigor of his rage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: Is't good to ſooth him in these contraries?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pinch.
SPEECH.LINE: It is no ſhame, the fellow finds his vaine,
And yeelding to him, humors well his frensie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou hast ſubborn’d the Goldsmith to arrest mee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas, I ſent you Monie to redeeme you,
By Dromio heere, who came in hast for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Monie by me? Heart and good will you might,
But ſurely Master not a ragge of Monie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Wentst not thou to her for a purse of Duckets.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adri.
SPEECH.LINE: He came to me, and I deliuer’d it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luci.
SPEECH.LINE: And I am witneſſe with her that ſhe did:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: God and the Rope-maker beare me witneſſe,
That I was ſent for nothing but a rope.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pinch.
SPEECH.LINE: Mistris, both Man and Master is poſſest,
I know it by their pale and deadly lookes,
They must be bound and laide in ſome darke roome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Say wherefore didst thou locke me forth to day,
And why dost thou denie the bagge of gold?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: I did not gentle husband locke thee forth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: And gentle Mr I receiu’d no gold:
But I confeſſe ſir, that we were lock’d out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: Diſſembling Villain, thou ſpeak'st false in both

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Diſſembling harlot, thou art false in all,
And art confederate with a damned packe,
To make a loathsome abiect ſcorne of me:
But with these nailes, Ile plucke out these false eyes,
That would behold in me this ſhamefull ſport.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter three or foure, and offer to binde him: Hee ſtriues

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh binde him, binde him, let him not come neere me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pinch.
SPEECH.LINE: More company, the fiend is ſtrong within him

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Aye me poore man, how pale and wan he looks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: What will you murther me, thou Iailor thou?
I am thy prisoner, wilt thou ſuffer them to make a res-cue?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Offi.
SPEECH.LINE: Masters let him go: he is my prisoner, and you ſhall not haue him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pinch.
SPEECH.LINE: Go binde this man, for he is franticke too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: What wilt thou do, thou peeuish Officer?
Hast thou delight to ſee a wretched man
Do outrage and displeasure to himselfe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Offi.
SPEECH.LINE: He is my prisoner, if I let him go,
The debt he owes will be requir’d of me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: I will discharge thee ere I go from thee,
Beare me forthwith vnto his Creditor,
And knowing how the debt growes I will pay it.
Good Master Doctor ſee him ſafe conuey’d
Home to my house, oh mo’t vnhappy day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh mo’t vnhappie ſtrumpet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Master, I am heere entred in bond for you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Out on thee Villaine, wherefore dost thou mad mee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Will you be bound for nothing, be mad good
Master, cry the diuell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: God helpe poore ſoules, how idlely doe they talke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: Go beare him hence, ſister go you with me:
Say now, whose ſuite is he arrested at?

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Exeunt. Manet Offic. Adri. Luci. Courtizan

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Off.
SPEECH.LINE: One Angelo a Goldsmith, do you know him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: I know the man: what is the ſumme he owes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Off.
SPEECH.LINE: Two hundred Duckets.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: Say, how growes it due.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Off.
SPEECH.LINE: Due for a Chaine your husband had of him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: He did bespeake a Chain for me, but had it not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cur.
SPEECH.LINE: When as your husband all in rage to day
Came to my house, and tooke away my Ring,
The Ring I ſaw vpon his finger now,
Straight after did I meete him with a Chaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: It may be ſo, but I did neuer ſee it. Come Iailor, bring me where the Goldsmith is, I long to know the truth heereof at large.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Antipholus Siracusia with his Rapier drawne, and Dromio Sirac

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: God for thy mercy, they are loose againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: And come with naked ſwords,
Let's call more helpe to haue them bound againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Off.
SPEECH.LINE: Away, they'l kill vs.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Exeunt omnes, as fast as may be, frighted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſee these Witches are affraid of ſwords.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: She that would be your wife, now ran from you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Come to the Centaur, fetch our ſtuffe from thence: I long that we were ſafe and ſound aboord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Faith ſtay heere this night, they will ſurely do vs no harme: you ſaw they ſpeake vs faire, giue vs gold: me thinkes they are ſuch a gentle Nation, that but for the Mountaine of mad flesh that claimes mariage of me, I could finde in my heart to ſtay heere ſtill, and turne Witch.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: I will not ſtay to night for all the Towne,
Therefore away, to get our ſtuffe aboord.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter the Merchant and the Goldsmith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gold.
SPEECH.LINE: I am ſorry Sir that I haue hindred you,
But I protest he had the Chaine of me,
Though mo’t dishonestly he doth denie it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: How is the man esteem’d heere in the Citie?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gold.
SPEECH.LINE: Of very reuerent reputation ſir,
Of credit infinite, highly belou’d,
Second to none that liues heere in the Citie:
His word might beare my wealth at any time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Speake ſoftly, yonder as I thinke he walkes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gold.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis ſo: and that ſelfe chaine about his necke,
Which he forswore mo’t monstrously to haue.
Good ſir draw neere to me, Ile ſpeake to him:
Signior Antipholus, I wonder much
That you would put me to this ſhame and trouble,
And not without ſome ſcandall to your ſelfe,
With circumstance and oaths, ſo to denie
This Chaine, which now you weare ſo openly.
Beside the charge, the ſhame, imprisonment,
You haue done wrong to this my honeſt friend,
Who but for ſtaying on our Controuersie,
Had hoisted ſaile, and put to ſea to day:
This Chaine you had of me, can you deny it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke I had, I neuer did deny it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes that you did ſir, and forswore it too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Who heard me to denie it or forsweare it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: These eares of mine thou knowst did hear thee:
Fie on thee wretch, ‘tis pitty that thou liu'st
To walke where any honeſt men resort.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou art a Villaine to impeach me thus,
Ile proue mine honor, and mine honestie
Against thee presently, if thou dar'st ſtand:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: I dare and do defie thee for a villaine.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: They draw. Enter Adriana, Luciana, Courtezan, & others.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: Hold, hurt him not for God ſake, he is mad,
Some get within him, take his ſword away:
Binde Dromio too, and beare them to my house.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Runne master run, for Gods ſake take a house,
This is ſome Priorie, in, or we are ſpoyl’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ab.
SPEECH.LINE: Be quiet people, wherefore throng you hither?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: To fetch my poore distracted husband hence,
Let vs come in, that we may binde him fast,
And beare him home for his recouerie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gold.
SPEECH.LINE: I knew he was not in his perfect wits.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: I am ſorry now that I did draw on him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ab.
SPEECH.LINE: How long hath this poſſeſſion held the man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: This weeke he hath beene heauie, ſower ſad,
And much different from the man he was:
But till this afternoone his paſſion
Ne're brake into extremity of rage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ab.
SPEECH.LINE: Hath he not lost much wealth by wrack of ſea,
Buried ſome deere friend, hath not else his eye
Stray’d his affection in vnlawfull loue,
A ſinne preuailing much in youthfull men,
Who giue their eies the liberty of gazing.
Which of these ſorrowes is he ſubiect too?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: To none of these, except it be the last,
Namely, ſome loue that drew him oft from home.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ab.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſhould for that haue reprehended him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ſo I did.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ab.
SPEECH.LINE: I but not rough enough.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: As roughly as my modestie would let me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ab.
SPEECH.LINE: Haply in priuate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: And in aſſemblies too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ab.
SPEECH.LINE: I, but not enough.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: It was the copie of our Conference.
In bed he ſlept not for my vrging it,
At boord he fed not for my vrging it:
Alone, it was the ſubiect of my Theame:
In company I often glanced it:
Still did I tell him, it was vilde and bad.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ab.
SPEECH.LINE: And thereof came it, that the man was mad.
The venome clamors of a iealous woman,
Poisons more deadly then a mad dogges tooth.
It ſeemes his ſleepes were hindred by thy railing,
And thereof comes it that his head is light.
Thou ſaist his meate was ſawc’d with thy vpbraidings,
Vnquiet meales make ill digestions,
Thereof the raging fire of feauer bred,
And what’s a Feauer, but a fit of madneſſe?
Thou ſayest his ſports were hindred by thy bralles.
Sweet recreation barr’d, what doth ensue
But moodie and dull melancholly,
Kinsman to grim and comfortleſſe dispaire,
And at her heeles a huge infectious troope
Of pale distemperatures, and fœs to life?
In food, in ſport, and life-preseruing rest
To be disturb’d, would mad or man, or beast:
The consequence is then, thy iealous fits
Hath ſcar’d thy husband from the vse of wits.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: She neuer reprehended him but mildely,
When he demean’d himselfe, rough, rude, and wildly,
Why beare you these rebukes, and anſwer not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adri.
