SPEECH.LINE: She did betray me to my owne reproofe,
Good people enter, and lay hold on him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ab.
SPEECH.LINE: No, not a creature enters in my house.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ad.
SPEECH.LINE: Then let your ſeruants bring my husband forth

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ab.
SPEECH.LINE: Neither: he tooke this place for ſanctuary,
And it ſhall priuiledge him from your hands,
Till I haue brought him to his wits againe,
Or loose my labour in aſſaying it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: I will attend my husband, be his nurse,
Diet his ſickneſſe, for it is my Office,
And will haue no atturney but my ſelfe,
And therefore let me haue him home with me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ab.
SPEECH.LINE: Be patient, for I will not let him ſtirre,
Till I haue vs’d the approoued meanes I haue,
With wholsome ſirrups, drugges, and holy prayers
To make of him a formall man againe:
It is a branch and parcell of mine oath,
A charitable dutie of my order,
Therefore depart, and leaue him heere with me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: I will not hence, and leaue my husband heere:
And ill it doth beseeme your holineſſe
To ſeparate the husband and the wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ab.
SPEECH.LINE: Be quiet and depart, thou ſhalt not haue him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Complaine vnto the Duke of this indignity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: Come go, I will fall prostrate at his feete,
And neuer rise vntill my teares and prayers
Haue won his grace to come in person hither,
And take perforce my husband from the Abbeſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: By this I thinke the Diall points at fiue:
Anon I'me ſure the Duke himselfe in person
Comes this way to the melancholly vale;
The place of depth, and ſorrie execution,
Behinde the ditches of the Abbey heere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gold.
SPEECH.LINE: Vpon what cause?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: To ſee a reuerent Siracusian Merchant,
Who put vnluckily into this Bay
Against the Lawes and Statutes of this Towne,
Beheaded publikely for his offence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gold.
SPEECH.LINE: See where they come, we wil behold his death

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Kneele to the Duke before he paſſe the Abbey.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter the Duke of Ephesus, and the Merchant of Siracuse bare head, with the Headsman, & other Officers

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Yet once againe proclaime it publikely,
If any friend will pay the ſumme for him,
He ſhall not die, ſo much we tender him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: Iustice mo’t ſacred Duke against the Abbeſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: She is a vertuous and a reuerend Lady,
It cannot be that ſhe hath done thee wrong.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: May it please your Grace, Antipholus my husba[n]d,
Who I made Lord of me, and all I had,
At your important Letters this ill day,
A mo’t outragious fit of madneſſe tooke him:
That desp'rately he hurried through the ſtreete,
With him his bondman, all as mad as he,
Doing displeasure to the Citizens,
By rushing in their houses: bearing thence
Rings, Iewels, any thing his rage did like.
Once did I get him bound, and ſent him home,
Whil'st to take order for the wrongs I went,
That heere and there his furie had committed,
Anon I wot not, by what ſtrong escape
He broke from those that had the guard of him,
And with his mad attendant and himselfe,
Each one with irefull paſſion, with drawne ſwords
Met vs againe, and madly bent on vs
Chac’d vs away: till raising of more aide
We came againe to binde them: then they fled
Into this Abbey, whether we pursu’d them,
And heere the Abbeſſe ſhuts the gates on vs,
And will not ſuffer vs to fetch him out,
Nor ſend him forth, that we may beare him hence.
Therefore mo’t gracious Duke with thy command,
Let him be brought forth, and borne hence for helpe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Long ſince thy husband ſeru’d me in my wars
And I to thee ingag’d a Princes word,
When thou didst make him Master of thy bed,
To do him all the grace and good I could.
Go ſome of you, knocke at the Abbey gate,
And bid the Lady Abbeſſe come to me:
I will determine this before I ſtirre.
Oh Mistris, Mistris, ſhift and ſaue your ſelfe,
My Master and his man are both broke loose,
Beaten the Maids a-row, and bound the Doctor,
Whose beard they haue ſindg’d off with brands of fire,
And euer as it blaz’d, they threw on him
Great pailes of puddled myre to quench the haire;
My Mr preaches patience to him, and the while
His man with Cizers nickes him like a foole:
And ſure (vnleſſe you ſend ſome present helpe)
Betweene them they will kill the Coniurer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace foole, thy Master and his man are here,
And that is false thou dost report to vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Mistris, vpon my life I tel you true,
I haue not breath’d almost ſince I did ſee it.
He cries for you, and vowes if he can take you,
To ſcorch your face, and to disfigure you:
Harke, harke, I heare him Mistris: flie, be gone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Come ſtand by me, feare nothing: guard with
Halberds.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: Ay me, it is my husband: witneſſe you,
That he is borne about inuisible,
Euen now we hous’d him in the Abbey heere.
And now he's there, past thought of humane reason.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Antipholus, and E. Dromio of Ephesus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Iustice mo’t gracious Duke, oh grant me iustice,
Euen for the ſeruice that long ſince I did thee,
When I bestrid thee in the warres, and tooke
Deepe ſcarres to ſaue thy life; euen for the blood
That then I lost for thee, now grant me iustice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.Fat.
SPEECH.LINE: Vnleſſe the feare of death doth make me dote, I ſee my ſonne Antipholus and Dromio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Iustice (sweet Prince) against y Woman there:
She whom thou gau'st to me to be my wife;
That hath abused and dishonored me,
Euen in the ſtrength and height of iniurie:
Beyond imagination is the wrong
That ſhe this day hath ſhameleſſe throwne on me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Discouer how, and thou ſhalt finde me iust.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: This day (great Duke) ſhe ſhut the doores vpon me, While ſhe with Harlots feasted in my house.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: A greeuous fault: ſay woman, didst thou ſo?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: No my good Lord. My ſelfe, he, and my ſister,
To day did dine together: ſo befall my ſoule,
As this is false he burthens me withall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Nere may I looke on day, nor ſleepe on night,
But ſhe tels to your Highneſſe ſimple truth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gold.
SPEECH.LINE: O periur’d woman! They are both forsworne,
In this the Madman iustly chargeth them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: My Liege, I am aduised what I ſay,
Neither disturbed with the effect of Wine,
Nor headie-rash prouoak’d with raging ire,
Albeit my wrongs might make one wiser mad.
This woman lock’d me out this day from dinner;
That Goldsmith there, were he not pack’d with her,
Could witneſſe it: for he was with me then,
Who parted with me to go fetch a Chaine,
Promising to bring it to the Porpentine,
Where Balthasar and I did dine together.
Our dinner done, and he not comming thither,
I went to ſeeke him. In the ſtreet I met him,
And in his companie that Gentleman.
There did this periur’d Goldsmith ſweare me downe,
That I this day of him receiu’d the Chaine,
Which God he knowes, I ſaw not. For the which,
He did arrest me with an Officer.
I did obey, and ſent my Pesant home
For certaine Duckets: he with none return’d.
Then fairely I bespoke the Officer
To go in person with me to my house.
By'th’ way, we met my wife, her ſister, and a rabble more
Of vilde Confederates: Along with them
They brought one Pinch, a hungry leane-fac’d Villaine;
A meere Anatomie, a Mountebanke,
A thred-bare Iugler, and a Fortune-teller,
A needy-hollow-ey’d-sharpe-looking-wretch;
A liuing dead man. This pernicious ſlaue,
Forsooth tooke on him as a Coniurer:
And gazing in mine eyes, feeling my pulse,
And with no-face (as 'twere) out-facing me,
Cries out, I was poſſest. Then altogether
They fell vpon me, bound me, bore me thence,
And in a darke and dankish vault at home
There left me and my man, both bound together,
Till gnawing with my teeth my bonds in ſunder,
I gain’d my freedome; and immediately
Ran hether to your Grace, whom I beseech
To giue me ample ſatisfaction
For these deepe ſhames, and great indignities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gold.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, in truth, thus far I witnes with him:
That he din’d not at home, but was lock’d out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: But had he ſuch a Chaine of thee, or no?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gold.
SPEECH.LINE: He had my Lord, and when he ran in heere,
These people ſaw the Chaine about his necke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Besides, I will be ſworne these eares of mine,
Heard you confeſſe you had the Chaine of him,
After you first forswore it on the Mart,
And thereupon I drew my ſword on you:
And then you fled into this Abbey heere,
From whence I thinke you are come by Miracle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: I neuer came within these Abbey wals,
Nor euer didst thou draw thy ſword on me:
I neuer ſaw the Chaine, ſo helpe me heauen:
And this is false you burthen me withall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Why what an intricate impeach is this?
I thinke you all haue drunke of Circes cup:
If heere you hous’d him, heere he would haue bin.
If he were mad, he would not pleade ſo coldly:
You ſay he din’d at home, the Goldsmith heere
Denies that ſaying. Sirra, what ſay you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir he din’de with her there, at the Porpen-tine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cur.
SPEECH.LINE: He did, and from my finger ſnacht that Ring.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Anti.
SPEECH.LINE: Tis true (my Liege) this Ring I had of her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Saw'st thou him enter at the Abbey heere?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Curt.
SPEECH.LINE: As ſure (my Liege) as I do ſee your Grace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Why this is ſtraunge: Go call the Abbeſſe hi-ther.
I thinke you are all mated, or ſtarke mad.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fa.
SPEECH.LINE: Mo’t mighty Duke, vouchsafe me ſpeak a word:
Haply I ſee a friend will ſaue my life,
And pay the ſum that may deliuer me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Speake freely Siracusian what thou wilt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fath.
SPEECH.LINE: Is not your name ſir call’d Antipholus?
And is not that your bondman Dromio?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Within this houre I was his bondman ſir,
But he I thanke him gnaw’d in two my cords,
Now am I Dromio, and his man, vnbound.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fath.
SPEECH.LINE: I am ſure you both of you remember me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Our ſelues we do remember ſir by you:
For lately we were bound as you are now.
You are not Pinches patient, are you ſir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Father.
SPEECH.LINE: Why looke you ſtrange on me? you know me well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: I neuer ſaw you in my life till now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fa.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh! griefe hath chang’d me ſince you ſaw me last,
And carefull houres with times deformed hand,
Haue written ſtrange defeatures in my face:
But tell me yet, dost thou not know my voice?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Neither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fat.
SPEECH.LINE: Dromio, nor thou?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: No trust me ſir, nor I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fa.
SPEECH.LINE: I am ſure thou dost?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Dromio.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſir, but I am ſure I do not, and whatso-euer a man denies, you are now bound to beleeue him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fath.
SPEECH.LINE: Not know my voice, oh times extremity
Hast thou ſo crack’d and ſplitted my poore tongue
In ſeuen ſhort yeares, that heere my onely ſonne
Knowes not my feeble key of vntun’d cares?
Though now this grained face of mine be hid
In ſap-consuming Winters drizled ſnow,
And all the Conduits of my blood froze vp:
Yet hath my night of life ſome memorie:
My wasting lampes ſome fading glimmer left;
My dull deafe eares a little vse to heare:
All these old witneſſes, I cannot erre.
Tell me, thou art my ſonne Antipholus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: I neuer ſaw my Father in my life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fa.
SPEECH.LINE: But ſeuen yeares ſince, in Siracusa boy
Thou know'st we parted, but perhaps my ſonne,
Thou ſham'st to acknowledge me in miserie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: The Duke, and all that know me in the City,
Can witneſſe with me that it is not ſo.
I ne're ſaw Siracusa in my life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: I tell thee Siracusian, twentie yeares Haue I bin Patron to Antipholus, During which time, he ne're ſaw Siracusa: I ſee thy age and dangers make thee dote.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter the Abbeſſe with Antipholus Siracusa, and Dromio Sir

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abbeſſe.
SPEECH.LINE: Mo’t mightie Duke, behold a man much wrong’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſee two husbands, or mine eyes deceiue me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: One of these men is genius to the other:
And ſo of these, which is the naturall man,
And which the ſpirit? Who deciphers them?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dromio.
SPEECH.LINE: I Sir am Dromio, command him away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: I Sir am Dromio, pray let me ſtay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Egeon art thou not? or else his ghoſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Drom.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh my olde Master, who hath bound him heere?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abb.
SPEECH.LINE: Who euer bound him, I will lose his bonds,
And gaine a husband by his libertie:
Speake olde Egeon, if thou bee'st the man
That hadst a wife once call’d Aemilia,
That bore thee at a burthen two faire ſonnes?
Oh if thou bee'st the ſame Egeon, ſpeake:
And ſpeake vnto the ſame Aemilia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Why heere begins his Morning ſtorie right:
These two Antipholus, these two ſo like,
And these two Dromio's, one in ſemblance:
Besides her vrging of her wracke at ſea,
These are the parents to these children,
Which accidentally are met together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fa.
SPEECH.LINE: If I dreame not, thou art Aemilia,
If thou art ſhe, tell me, where is that ſonne
That floated with thee on the fatall rafte.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abb.
SPEECH.LINE: By men of Epidamium, he, and I,
And the twin Dromio, all were taken vp;
But by and by, rude Fishermen of Corinth
By force tooke Dromio, and my ſonne from them,
And me they left with those of Epidamium.
What then became of them, I cannot tell:
I, to this fortune that you ſee mee in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Antipholus thou cam'st from Corinth first.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: No ſir, not I, I came from Siracuse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Stay, ſtand apart, I know not which is which.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: I came from Corinth my mo’t gracious Lord

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: And I with him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Brought to this Town by that mo’t famous
Warriour,
Duke Menaphon your mo’t renowned Vnckle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: Which of you two did dine with me to day?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: I, gentle Mistris.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: And are not you my husband?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: No, I ſay nay to that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: And ſo do I, yet did ſhe call me ſo:
And this faire Gentlewoman her ſister heere
Did call me brother. What I told you then,
I hope I ſhall haue leisure to make good,
If this be not a dreame I ſee and heare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goldsmith.
SPEECH.LINE: That is the Chaine ſir, which you had of mee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke it be ſir, I denie it not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: And you ſir for this Chaine arrested me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gold.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke I did ſir, I deny it not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſent you monie ſir to be your baile
By Dromio, but I thinke he brought it not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: No, none by me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: This purse of Duckets I receiu’d from you,
And Dromio my man did bring them me:
I ſee we ſtill did meete each others man,
And I was tane for him, and he for me,
And thereupon these errors are arose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: These Duckets pawne I for my father heere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: It ſhall not neede, thy father hath his life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cur.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir I must haue that Diamond from you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: There take it, and much thanks for my good cheere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abb.
SPEECH.LINE: Renowned Duke, vouchsafe to take the paines
To go with vs into the Abbey heere,
And heare at large discoursed all our fortunes,
And all that are aſſembled in this place:
That by this ſimpathized one daies error
Haue ſuffer’d wrong. Goe, keepe vs companie,
And we ſhall make full ſatisfaction.
Thirtie three yeares haue I but gone in trauaile
Of you my ſonnes, and till this present houre
My heauie burthen are deliuered:
The Duke my husband, and my children both,
And you the Kalenders of their Natiuity,
Go to a Goſſips feast, and go with mee,
After ſo long greefe ſuch Natiuitie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: With all my heart, Ile Goſſip at this feast.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Exeunt omnes. Manet the two Dromio's and two Brothers

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Mast[er]. ſhall I fetch your ſtuffe from ſhipbord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.An.
SPEECH.LINE: Dromio, what ſtuffe of mine hast thou imbarkt

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Your goods that lay at host ſir in the Centaur.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: He ſpeakes to me, I am your master Dromio.
Come go with vs, wee'l looke to that anon,
Embrace thy brother there, reioyce with him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: There is a fat friend at your masters house,
That kitchin’d me for you to day at dinner:
She now ſhall be my ſister, not my wife,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.D.
SPEECH.LINE: Me thinks you are my glaſſe, & not my brother:
I ſee by you, I am a ſweet-fac’d youth,
Will you walke in to ſee their goſſipping?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Not I ſir, you are my elder.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: That's a question, how ſhall we trie it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: S.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Wee'l draw Cuts for the Signior, till then, lead thou first.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: E.Dro.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay then thus:
We came into the world like brother and brother:
And now let's go hand in hand, not one before another.
